form.longName: PhenX PX021601 - Waist Circumference Adolescent Protocol
form.preferredDefinition: Waist circumference is measured at several body sites in the scientific literature. For the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES), the measurement of the participant’s abdominal (waist) circumference is made at the uppermost lateral border of the ilium using a tape measure. This measurement protocol was developed specifically for NHANES III (1988-1994) to improve reliability by standardizing the bony landmarks needed to determine the plane for measurement, and it is rarely used outside of the United States. In both children and adults, and compared with measurements taken using other protocols, measurements taken over the iliac crest tend to be several centimeters larger than measurements taken midway between the lowest rib and iliac crest (Protocol 021601) or at the level of the umbilicus (Protocol 021603), except when waist circumference is measured at the level of the umbilicus in an obese participant and the umbilicus has been displaced downward (i.e., pendulous abdomen). This protocol is recommended for use by the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute to define central obesity (greater than 102 cm in men; greater than 88 cm in women), and references by race/ethnicity have been developed for children and adolescents. It should not be used to calculate a waist-to-height ratio (WHtR) because it will overestimate the prevalence in the abnormal range (WHtR greater than 0.5). The relationship of this measure with cardiometabolic risk factors is, however, comparable with waist circumference measures taken at other sites. NOTE: Waist circumference can be measured on pregnant women. However, national reference data do not include pregnant women, and waist circumference has different associations with abdominal and total body fat among those who are not pregnant.

form.longName: PhenX PX100403 - Difficulty Getting Pregnant Prospective Assessment
form.preferredDefinition: Depending on the aims of the project and feasibility, there are three widely used methods to assess difficulty getting pregnant or impaired fecundity. These include: retrospective assessment, prospective assessment, and the current duration approach. For the retrospective approach (also the approach used for cross-sectional studies), women or couples are asked if the pregnancy was planned and if yes, how many months it took to get pregnant. It is important to note that this approach can only be used with women or couples who planned their pregnancies. For prospective assessment, women or couples are followed over time as they try to get pregnant. Women or couples are asked to record exposure data, menstrual cycle data, intercourse, and pregnancy status prospectively over time. Again, this method can only be employed with women or couples who are planning a pregnancy. If investigators are interested in exposures among women or couples who are not planning a pregnancy, the current duration approach can be used. For this approach, women or couples are asked about the date that they last used contraception.

form.longName: PhenX PX120602 - Eating Disorder Diagnostic Scale Dsm-5
form.preferredDefinition: This protocol is a revised version of the Eating Disorder Diagnostic Scale (EDDS) that is updated for diagnostic changes in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, 5th Ed. (DSM-5). The EDDS-5 is a 23-item self-report scale that simultaneously assesses anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa, and binge eating disorder by asking the respondent about body image, eating habits, and compensatory behaviors over the last 3-6 months. The EDDS-5 does not include pica (persistent eating of substances with no nutrition, such as dirt or paint), rumination disorder, or avoidant/restrictive food intake disorder (ARFID).

question.questionText: have you felt fat? (EDDS5_ThreeMonths_Felt_Fat)
have you had a definite fear that you might gain weight or become fat? (EDDS5_ThreeMonths_Fear_GainWeight)
has your weight or shape influenced how you judge yourself as a person? (EDDS5_ThreeMonths_WeightShape_Influence)

During the past 3 months have there been times when you have eaten what other people would regard as an unusually large amount of food (e.g., a pint of ice cream) given the circumstances? (EDDS5_ThreeMonths_UnusualAmount)

During the times when you ate an unusually large amount of food, did you experience a loss of control (e.g., felt you couldn't stop eating or control what or how much you were eating? (EDDS5_ThreeMonths_UnusualAmount_LossOfControl)
How many times per month on average over the past 3 months have you eaten an unusually large amount of food and experienced a loss of control? (EDDS5_ThreeMonths_UnusualAmount_Frequency)
During episodes of overeating with a loss of control: (EDDS5_Episodes_LossOfControl_desc)
did you eat much more rapidly than normal? (EDDS5_Episodes_LossOfControl_EatRapidly)
did you eat until you felt uncomfortably full? (EDDS5_Episodes_LossOfControl_UncomfortablyFull)
did you eat large amounts of food when you didn't feel physically hungry? (EDDS5_Episodes_LossOfControl_NotHungry)
did you eat alone because you were embarrassed by how much you were eating? (EDDS5_Episodes_LossOfControl_EatAlone)
did you feel disgusted with yourself, depressed, or very guilty after overeating? (EDDS5_Episodes_LossOfControl_FeelDisgustedDepressed)
If you have episodes of uncontrollable overeating, does it make you very upset? (EDDS5_Episodes_LossOfControl_FeelUpset)
How many times per month on average over the past 3 months: (EDDS5_ThreeMonths_Frequency_desc)
have you made yourself vomit? (EDDS5_ThreeMonths_Frequency_Vomit)
have you used laxatives or diuretics? (EDDS5_ThreeMonths_Frequency_Laxatives)
have you fasted (skipped at least 2 meals in a row)? (EDDS5_ThreeMonths_Frequency_Fasting)
have you engaged in more intense exercise specifically to counteract the effects of overeating? (EDDS5_ThreeMonths_Frequency_Exercise)
have you eaten after awakening from sleep or eaten an unusually large amount of food after your evening meal and felt distressed by the night eating? (EDDS5_ThreeMonths_Frequency_LateNight)
How much do eating or body image problems impact your relationships with friends and family, work performance, and school performance? (EDDS5_Eating_Impact_On_Relationships)
How much do you weigh? If uncertain, please give your best estimate. (EDDS5_Weight)
How tall are you? (EDDS5_Height)
What is your highest weight at your current height? (EDDS5_Heaviest_AtHeight)
What is your sex? (EDDS5_Sex)
What is your age? (EDDS5_Age)

form.longName: PhenX PX121002 - Sleep Disorders Screener Children
form.preferredDefinition: The Sleep Disturbances Scale for Children is a 26-item, self-administered scale completed by the parent that assesses the child's sleep behaviors in the past 6 months. The scale includes six subscales: disorders of initiating and maintaining sleep (items 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 10, 11); sleep breathing disorders (items 13, 14, 15); disorders of arousal (items 17, 20, 21); sleep-wake transition disorders (items 6, 7, 8, 12, 18, 19); disorders of excessive somnolence (items 22, 23, 24, 25, 26); and sleep hyperhidrosis (score of the items 9, 16). Each item is rated on a 5-point, Likert-type scale (1 = Never; 5 = Always [daily]). Scores from individual items of each subscale are added together to give a subscale score, with higher scores indicating greater symptoms. Scores from the individual subscales can be added together to give a total score.

question.questionText: How many hours of sleep does your child get on most nights? (sleep_disorders_screener_hours_sleep)
How long after going to bed does your child usually fall asleep? (sleep_disorders_screener_fall_asleep)
The child goes to bed reluctantly. (sleep_disorders_screener_reluctant)
The child has difficulty getting to sleep at night. (sleep_disorders_screener_difficulty_getting_to_sleep)
The child feels anxious or afraid when falling asleep. (sleep_disorders_screener_feels_anxious)
The child startles or jerks parts of the body while falling asleep. (sleep_disorders_screener_startles_jerks)
The child shows repetitive actions such as rocking or head banging while falling asleep. (sleep_disorders_screener_repetitive_actions)
The child experiences vivid dream-like scenes while falling asleep. (sleep_disorders_screener_vivid_dream)
The child sweats excessively while falling asleep. (sleep_disorders_screener_sweats_excessively_while_falling_asleep)
The child wakes up more than twice per night. (sleep_disorders_screener_wakes_up)
After waking up in the night, the child has difficulty to fall asleep again. (sleep_disorders_screener_difficulty_falling_back_to_sleep)
The child has frequent twitching or jerking of legs while asleep or often changes position during the night or kicks the covers off the bed. (sleep_disorders_screener_twitching_jerking_legs)
The child has difficulty breathing during the night. (sleep_disorders_screener_difficulty_breathing)
The child gasps for breath or is unable to breathe during sleep. (sleep_disorders_screener_gasp_for_breath)
The child snores. (sleep_disorders_screener_snores)
The child sweats excessively during the night. (sleep_disorders_screener_sweats_excessively_during_the_night)
You have observed the child sleepwalking. (sleep_disorders_screener_sleepwalking)
You have observed the child talking in his/her sleep. (sleep_disorders_screener_talking_in_sleep)
The child grinds teeth during sleep. (sleep_disorders_screener_grinds_teeth)

The child wakes from sleep screaming or confused so that you cannot seem to get through to him/her, but has no memory of these events the next morning. (sleep_disorders_screener_screams_confused_no_memory)
The child has nightmares which he/she doesn't remember the next day. (sleep_disorders_screener_nightmares_no_memory)
The child is unusually difficult to wake up in the morning. (sleep_disorders_screener_difficult_wake_up)
The child awakes in the morning feeling tired. (sleep_disorders_screener_awakes_tired)
The child feels unable to move when waking up in the morning. (sleep_disorders_screener_unable_to_move_waking)
The child experiences daytime somnolence. (sleep_disorders_screener_daytime_somnolence)
The child falls asleep suddenly in inappropriate situations. (sleep_disorders_screener_falls_asleep_suddenly_inappropriate_situations)

form.longName: PhenX PX220501 - Complete Blood Count Cbc
form.preferredDefinition: The Complete Blood Count (CBC) protocol is a standard blood panel from the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) and performed on participants aged 1 and older. Blood is collected from participants via standard venipuncture in a 3 or 4 ml K<sub>3</sub> EDTA tube. The ambient blood sample is placed into a hematological analyzer for CBC and differential analyses. The blood should be tested as soon as possible after venipuncture and no later than 24 hours.

form.longName: PhenX PX221302 - Quality Of Life - Adult
form.preferredDefinition: This protocol includes 29 self-administered quality of life-type questions from the PROMIS® Profile 29 for adults. The quality of life questions include physical function, anxiety, depression, fatigue, sleep disturbance, ability to participate in social roles and activities, and pain intensity over the past 7 days. Each question, except for the pain intensity question, is measured on a 5-point scale.

question.questionText: Are you able to do chores such as vacuuming or yard work? (QualityOfLifeForAdults_Able_Do_Chores)
Are you able to go up and down stairs at a normal pace (QualityOfLifeForAdults_Able_UpDown_Stairs_Normal)
Are you able to go for a walk of at least 15 minutes? (QualityOfLifeForAdults_Able_Walk_Least_15minutes)
Are you able to run errands and shop? ...... (QualityOfLifeForAdults_Able_Errands_Shop)
In the past 7 days, I felt fearful (QualityOfLifeForAdults_Felt_Fearful_Past7days)

protocol.preferredDefinition: This protocol includes 29 self-administered quality of life-type questions from the PROMIS® Profile 29 for adults. The quality of life questions include physical function, anxiety, depression, fatigue, sleep disturbance, ability to participate in social roles and activities, and pain intensity over the past 7 days. Each question, except for the pain intensity question, is measured on a 5-point scale.

form.longName: PhenX PX250201 - Auditory Perception And Noise Exposure
form.preferredDefinition: Determination of fetal growth is a three-step process: Step 1: Ascertainment of estimated fetal weight (EFW) Step 2: Verification of gestational age (GA) at which the EFW was recorded Step 3: Determination of EFW or biometry percentiles by plotting the EFW or relevant biometric measures at the appropriate GA on a pre-defined fetal growth curve

question.questionText: Which statement best describes {your/SP's} hearing (without a hearing aid or other listening devices)? Would you say {your/his/her} hearing is excellent, good, that {you have/s/he has} a little trouble, moderate trouble, a lot of trouble, or {are you/is s/he} deaf? (Auditory_Perception_Noise_Exposure_Hearing_Rating)

Can {you/SP} usually hear and understand what a person says without seeing his or her face if that person whispers to {you/him/her} from across a quiet room? (Auditory_Perception_Noise_Exposure_Hearing_Without_Face_Whisper)

Can {you/SP} usually hear and understand what a person says without seeing his or her face if that person talks in a normal voice to {you/him/her} from across a quiet room? (Auditory_Perception_Noise_Exposure_Hearing_Without_Face_Normal_Voice)

Can {you/SP} usually hear and understand what a person says without seeing his or her face if that person shouts to {you/him/her} from across a quiet room? (Auditory_Perception_Noise_Exposure_Hearing_Without_Face_Shouting)

Can {you/SP} usually hear and understand what a person says without seeing his or her face if that person speaks loudly into {your/his/her} better ear? INTERVIEWER: IF THE INTERVIEWEE HEARS BETTER IN ONE EAR THAN THE OTHER, RECORD THE RESPONSE FOR SPEAKING LOUDLY INTO THE BETTER EAR. (Auditory_Perception_Noise_Exposure_Hearing_Without_Face_Better_Ear)

How often {do you/does SP} find it difficult to follow a conversation if there is background noise, for example, when other people are talking, TV or radio is on, or children are playing? Would you say... (Auditory_Perception_Noise_Exposure_Conversation_Background_Noise_Difficulty)

How often does {your/SP's} hearing cause {you/him/her} to feel frustrated when talking to members of {your/his/her} family or to friends? Would you say... (Auditory_Perception_Noise_Exposure_Frustration)

{Have you/Has SP} ever had 3 = or more ear infections? Please include ear infections {you/he/she} may have had when {you were/he was/she was} a child. (Auditory_Perception_Noise_Exposure_Ear_Infections)
{Have you/Has SP} ever had a tube placed in {your/his/her} ear to drain the fluid from {your/his/her} ear? (Auditory_Perception_Noise_Exposure_Tube_Drain_Fluid)

A hearing test by a specialist is one that is done in a sound proof booth or room, or with headphones. Hearing specialists include audiologists, ear nose and throat doctors, and trained technicians or occupational nurses. When was the last time {you had/SP had} {your/his/her} hearing tested by a hearing specialist? READ CATEGORIES IF NECESSARY (Auditory_Perception_Noise_Exposure_Hearing_Specialist_Testing)
{Have you/Has SP} ever worn a hearing aid or cochlear implant? (Auditory_Perception_Noise_Exposure_Hearing_Aid_Implant)

Hearing Aid: A small electronic device that amplifies the sounds you hear. It is worn in or behind the ear to help you hear. Cochlear Implant: A cochlear implant is an electrical device that a surgeon puts in your ear. It helps you hear by sending sounds directly to the brain. It is used only when you are almost totally deaf. Which was it? CODE ALL THAT APPLY (Auditory_Perception_Noise_Exposure_Hearing_Aid_Type)
In the past 12 = months, how often {have you/has SP} worn a hearing aid? (Auditory_Perception_Noise_Exposure_Hearing_Aid_Past_Year)

{Have you/Has SP} ever used assistive listening devices (ALDs), such as FM systems, closed-captioned television, amplified telephone, relay services, or a sign-language interpreter? (Auditory_Perception_Noise_Exposure_Assistive_Listening_Devices)

In the past 12 = months, {have you/has SP} been bothered by ringing, roaring, or buzzing in {your/his/her} ears or head that lasts for 5 = minutes or more? (Auditory_Perception_Noise_Exposure_Ringing_Roaring_Buzzing_Past_Year)

How long {have you/has SP} been bothered by this ringing, roaring, or buzzing in {your/his/her} ears or head? READ CATEGORIES IF NECESSARY (Auditory_Perception_Noise_Exposure_Ringing_Roaring_Buzzing_History)

In the past 12 = months, how often {have you/has SP} had this ringing, roaring, or buzzing in {your/his/her} ears or head? Would you say... (Auditory_Perception_Noise_Exposure_Ringing_Roaring_Buzzing_Frequency)

validValue.meaningText: less frequently than once a month
validValue.description: less frequently than once a month

question.questionText: {Are you/Is SP} bothered by ringing, roaring, or buzzing in {your/his/her} ears or head only after listening to loud sounds or loud music? (Auditory_Perception_Noise_Exposure_Ringing_Roaring_Buzzing_Loud_Music_Sound)
{Are you/Is SP} bothered by ringing, roaring, or buzzing in {your/his/her} ears or head when going to sleep? (Auditory_Perception_Noise_Exposure_Ringing_Roaring_Buzzing_Sleep)
How much of a problem is this ringing, roaring, or buzzing in {your/his/her} ears or head? (Auditory_Perception_Noise_Exposure_Ringing_Roaring_Buzzing_Problem_Rating)

This next question is about {your/SP's} use of firearms that {you/he/she} may have used for target shooting, hunting, for {your/his/her} job or in military service. {Have you/Has SP} ever used firearms for any reason? (Auditory_Perception_Noise_Exposure_Firearms_Usage)

How many total rounds {have you/has SP} ever fired? READ CATEGORIES IF NECESSARY. INTERVIEWER: ONE ROUND EQUALS ONE SHOT. INCLUDE TARGET SHOOTING, HUNTING, YOUR JOB, AND MILITARY SERVICE. (Auditory_Perception_Noise_Exposure_Firearms_Usage_History)
How often {did you/did SP} wear hearing protection devices (ear plugs, ear muffs) when shooting firearms? (Auditory_Perception_Noise_Exposure_Firearms_Safety_Protection)

{Have you/Has SP} ever had a job, or combination of jobs where {you were/s/he was} exposed to loud sounds or noise for 4 = or more hours a day, several days a week? Loud means so loud that {you/s/he} must speak in a raised voice to be heard. (Auditory_Perception_Noise_Exposure_Job_Loud_Noise_Sound)

For how many months or years {have you/has SP} been exposed at work to loud sounds or noise for 4 = or more hours a day, several days a week? READ CATEGORIES IF NECESSARY (Auditory_Perception_Noise_Exposure_Job_Loud_Noise_Sound_History)

In {your/SP's} work {were you/was he/was she} exposed to very loud noise? Very loud noise is noise that is so loud {you have/he has/she has} to shout in order to be understood by someone standing 3 = feet away from {you/him/her}. (Auditory_Perception_Noise_Exposure_Job_Very_Loud_Noise_Sound)

This next question is about {your/SP's} work in jobs where there was very loud noise for 4 = or more hours a day, several days a week. Please give me the total number of months or years for all jobs where this has happened. READ CATEGORIES IF NECESSARY (Auditory_Perception_Noise_Exposure_Job_Very_Loud_Noise_Sound_History)

Outside of a job, {have you/has SP} ever been exposed to very loud noise or music for 10 or more hours a week? This is noise so loud that {you have/s/he has} to shout to be understood or heard 3 = feet away. Examples are noise from power tools, lawn mowers, farm machinery, cars, trucks, motorcycles, motor boats, or loud music. (Auditory_Perception_Noise_Exposure_Loud_Noise_Sound)

In the past 12 = months, how often {did you/did SP} wear hearing protection devices (ear plugs, ear muffs) when exposed to very loud sounds or noise? Please include both on the job and off the job exposures. DEFINITIONS: Protective Hearing Device: These protect you from noise that is so loud that it might damage your hearing. Examples are ear plugs, protective earmuffs, or special headphones. (Auditory_Perception_Noise_Exposure_Loud_Noise_Sound_Hearing_Protection)

Please describe the taste or other sensation in {your/SP's} mouth that does not go away. Would {you/he/she} say it is? (Smell_Taste_Describe)

During the past 12 months, {have you/has SP} experienced a problem with {your/his/her} general health, work or {your/his/her} enjoyment of life because of a problem with {your/his/her) ability to taste or smell? (Smell_Taste_Twelve_Months_Problem_Life)

protocol.preferredDefinition: Determination of fetal growth is a three-step process: Step 1: Ascertainment of estimated fetal weight (EFW) Step 2: Verification of gestational age (GA) at which the EFW was recorded Step 3: Determination of EFW or biometry percentiles by plotting the EFW or relevant biometric measures at the appropriate GA on a pre-defined fetal growth curve

form.preferredDefinition: The Smoking Consequences Questionnaire-Adult (BSCQ-A) is a questionnaire assessing various outcome expectancies associated with smoking behavior, based on the notion that as substance users become more experienced, they move from having general to more specific and refined expectancies for their substance use. Thus, it is used for assessing expectancies in adult smokers. The BSCQ-A includes 10 subscales, each assessing a different domain of smoking expectancies. It can be used with chronic smokers who have psychiatric comorbidities. The BSCQ-A contains 25 statements describing possible consequences of smoking cigarettes, and respondents rate the likelihood of the consequence occurring on a 10-point scale ranging from 0 (completely unlikely) to 9 (completely likely).

question.questionText: Rate how likely or unlikely you believe the following consequence has on you when you smoke: (expectancies_tobacco_desc)
My throat burns after smoking. (expectancies_tobacco_throat_burns)
I enjoy the taste sensations while smoking. (expectancies_tobacco_taste_sensations)
Nicotine "fits" can be controlled by smoking. (expectancies_tobacco_nicotine_fits)
When I'm angry, a cigarette can calm me down. (expectancies_tobacco_calm_anger)
When I'm alone, a cigarette can help me pass the time. (expectancies_tobacco_pass_time_alone)
Smoking a cigarette energizes me. (expectancies_tobacco_energizing)
Smoking calms me down when I feel nervous. (expectancies_tobacco_calm_nervousness)
A cigarette can give me energy when I'm bored and tired. (expectancies_tobacco_energizing_boredom)
I will enjoy the flavor of a cigarette. (expectancies_tobacco_enjoy_flavor)
If I have nothing to do, a smoke can help kill time. (expectancies_tobacco_pass_time)
When I smoke, the taste is pleasant. (expectancies_tobacco_taste_pleasant)
Smoking will satisfy my nicotine cravings. (expectancies_tobacco_satisfy_cravings)
I feel like part of a group when I'm around other smokers. (expectancies_tobacco_feel_included)
Smoking makes me seem less attractive. (expectancies_tobacco_less_attractive)
By smoking, I risk heart disease and lung cancer. (expectancies_tobacco_risk_cancer)
Smoking helps me enjoy people more. (expectancies_tobacco_enjoy_people)
People think less of me if they see me smoking. (expectancies_tobacco_judgement)
If I'm feeling irritable, a smoke will help me relax. (expectancies_tobacco_relaxing)
Smoking irritates my mouth and throat. (expectancies_tobacco_irritating)
Smoking helps me control my weight. (expectancies_tobacco_control_weight)
The more I smoke, the more I risk my health. (expectancies_tobacco_risk_health)
Cigarettes keep me from eating more than I should. (expectancies_tobacco_appetite)
Smoking keeps my weight down. (expectancies_tobacco_maintain_weight)
I look ridiculous while smoking. (expectancies_tobacco_appear_ridiculous)
I feel more at ease with other people if I have a cigarette. (expectancies_tobacco_social_anxiety)

form.longName: PhenX PX540401 - Peer Partner Substance Use And Tolerance Of Substance Us
form.preferredDefinition: This protocol includes two self-administered subscales from the 2009 Monitoring the Future (MTF) project survey. The Friends’ Use of Substances subscale includes 14 questions taken from form 2 of the 12th-grade survey. The Friends’ Attitudes About Your Use subscale includes 13 questions taken from form 6 of the 12th-grade survey.

module.longName: Peer Partner Substance Use And Tolerance Of Substance Us
module.preferredDefinition: Peer Partner Substance Use And Tolerance Of Substance Us

question.questionText: How many of your friends would you estimate smoke cigarettes? (number_friends_smoke_cigarettes)
How many of your friends would you estimate smoke marijuana (pot, weed) or hashish? (number_friends_smoke_marijuana)
How many of your friends would you estimate take LSD? (friends_take_lsd)
How many of your friends would you estimate take other hallucinogens (mescaline, peyote, shrooms or psilocybin etc.)? (friends_take_other_hallucinogens)
How many of your friends would you estimate take amphetamines (uppers, pep pills, bennies, speed)? (number_friends_take_amphetamines)
How many of your friends would you estimate take Quaaludes (quads, methaqualone)? (number_friends_take_quaalude)
How many of your friends would you estimate take sedatives/barbiturates (downers)? (number_friends_take_sedatives)
How many of your friends would you estimate take tranquilizers? (number_friends_take_tranquilizers)
How many of your friends would you estimate take cocaine? (number_friends_take_cocaine)
How many of your friends would you estimate take heroin? (number_friends_take_heroin)
How many of your friends would you estimate take other narcotics (methadone, opium, codeine, etc.)? (number_friends_take_other_narcotic)
How many of your friends would you estimate use inhalants (sniff glue, aerosols, laughing gas, etc.)? (number_friends_use_inhalants)
How many of your friends would you estimate drink alcoholic beverages (liquor, beer, wine)? (number_friends_drink_alcohol)
How many of your friends would you estimate get drunk at least once a week? (number_friends_get_drunk_weekly)
How do you think your CLOSE FRIENDS feel (or would feel) about YOU doing each of the following things? Smoking one or more packs of cigarettes per day (friends_feel_about_smoking)
How do you think your CLOSE FRIENDS feel (or would feel) about YOU doing each of the following things? Trying marijuana (pot, weed) once or twice (friends_feel_about_trying_marijuana)
How do you think your CLOSE FRIENDS feel (or would feel) about YOU doing each of the following things? Smoking marijuana occasionally (friends_feel_about_marijuana_occasionally)
How do you think your CLOSE FRIENDS feel (or would feel) about YOU doing each of the following things? Smoking marijuana regularly (friends_feel_about_marijuana_regularly)
How do you think your CLOSE FRIENDS feel (or would feel) about YOU doing each of the following things? Trying LSD once or twice (friends_feel_about_trying_lsd)

How do you think your CLOSE FRIENDS feel (or would feel) about YOU doing each of the following things? Trying an amphetamine (upper, pep pill, bennie, speed) once or twice (friends_feel_about_trying_amphetamine)
How do you think your CLOSE FRIENDS feel (or would feel) about YOU doing each of the following things? Trying cocaine once or twice (friends_feel_about_trying_cocaine)
How do you think your CLOSE FRIENDS feel (or would feel) about YOU doing each of the following things? Taking cocaine occasionally (friends_feel_about_cocaine_occasionally)
How do you think your CLOSE FRIENDS feel (or would feel) about YOU doing each of the following things? Taking one or two drinks nearly every day (friends_feel_about_oneortwo_drinksdaily)
How do you think your CLOSE FRIENDS feel (or would feel) about YOU doing each of the following things? Taking four or five drinks nearly every day (friends_feel_about_fourorfive_drinksdaily)

How do you think your CLOSE FRIENDS feel (or would feel) about YOU doing each of the following things? Having five or more drinks once or twice each weekend (friends_feel_about_fiveormore_drinksweekend)
How do you think your CLOSE FRIENDS feel (or would feel) about YOU doing each of the following things? Driving a car after having 1-2 drinks (friends_feel_about_drivingafter_coupledrinks)
How do you think your CLOSE FRIENDS feel (or would feel) about YOU doing each of the following things? Driving a car after having 5 or more drinks (friends_feel_about_drivingafter_5ormoredrinks)

form.longName: PhenX PX661501 - Perception Of Recovery Orientation And Care Quality Of M
form.preferredDefinition: The Recovery Self-Assessment (RSA) administrator/manager version is a 36-item, provider-completed rating scale that focuses on perceptions of recovery principles and overall quality of services, including determination, staff helpfulness, and staff responsiveness. The RSA includes six subscales: life goals, consumer involvement and diversity of treatment options, consumer choice, individually tailored services, and inviting environment. Each item is rated on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree). Ratings from the individual items can be added together to yield a total score, with the higher scores indicating greater quality care.

module.longName: Perception Of Recovery Orientation And Care Quality Of M
module.preferredDefinition: Perception Of Recovery Orientation And Care Quality Of M

question.questionText: Staff make a concerted effort to welcome people in recovery and help them to feel comfortable in this program. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_administrator_welcoming_staff)

This program/agency offers an inviting and dignified physical environment (e.g., the lobby, waiting rooms, etc.). Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_administrator_facilities)

Staff encourage program participants to have hope and high expectations for their recovery. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_administrator_encouragement)
Program participants can change their clinician or case manager if they wish. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_administrator_flexibility)

Program participants can easily access their treatment records if they wish. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_administrator_treatment_records)

Staff do not use threats, bribes, or other forms of pressure to influence the behavior of program participants. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_administrator_threats_bribes)
Staff believe in the ability of program participants to recover. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_administrator_staff_hopeful)

Staff believe that program participants have the ability to manage their own symptoms. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_administrator_symptoms)

Staff believe that program participants can make their own life choices regarding things such as where to live, when to work, whom to be friends with, etc. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_administrator_independence)

Staff listen to and respect the decisions that program participants make about their treatment and care. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_administrator_decisions)

Staff regularly ask program participants about their interests and the things they would like to do in the community. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_administrator_interests)
Staff encourage program participants to take risks and try new things. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_administrator_risks)

This program offers specific services that fit each participant’s unique culture and life experiences. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_administrator_cultural_acceptance)

Staff offer participants opportunities to discuss their spiritual needs and interests when they wish. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_administrator_spiritual_needs)

Staff offer participants opportunities to discuss their sexual needs and interests when they wish. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_administrator_sexual_needs)

Staff help program participants to develop and plan for life goals beyond managing symptoms or staying stable (e.g., employment, education, physical fitness, connecting with family and friends, hobbies). Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_administrator_life_goals)
Staff routinely assist program participants with getting jobs. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_administrator_job_search)

Staff actively help program participants to get involved in non-mental health/addiction related activities, such as church groups, adult education, sports, or hobbies. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_administrator_other_activities)

Staff work hard to help program participants to include people who are important to them in their recovery/treatment planning (such as family, friends, clergy, or an employer). Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_administrator_support_network)

Staff actively introduce program participants to persons in recovery who can serve as role models or mentors. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_administrator_role_models)

Staff actively connect program participants with self-help, peer support, or consumer advocacy groups and programs. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_administrator_network)

Staff actively help people find ways to give back to their community (i.e., volunteering, community services, neighborhood watch/cleanup). Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_administrator_volunteering)

People in recovery are encouraged to help staff with the development of new groups, programs, or services. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_administrator_new_development)

People in recovery are encouraged to be involved in the evaluation of this agency’s programs, services, and service providers. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_administrator_evaluation)

People in recovery are encouraged to attend agency advisory boards and management meetings. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_administrator_attend_meetings)

Staff talk with program participants about what it takes to complete or exit the program. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_administrator_complete_program)

Progress made towards an individual’s own personal goals is tracked regularly. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_administrator_personal_goals)

The primary role of agency staff is to assist a person with fulfilling his/her own goals and aspirations. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_administrator_assist)

Persons in recovery are involved with facilitating staff trainings and education at this program. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_administrator_help_train)
Staff at this program regularly attend trainings on cultural competency. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_administrator_staff_training)

Staff are knowledgeable about special interest groups and activities in the community. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_administrator_specialinterest_groups)

Agency staff are diverse in terms of culture, ethnicity, lifestyle, and interests. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_administrator_diversity)

[For Administrators Only] This agency provides formal opportunities for people in recovery, family members, service providers, and administrators to learn about recovery. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_administrator_education)

[For Administrators Only] This agency provides structured educational activities to the community about mental illness and addictions. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_administrator_structured_education)

[For Administrators Only] This agency provides a variety of treatment options for program participants (e.g., individual, group, peer support, medical, community-based, employment, skill building, employment, etc.). Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_administrator_treatment_options)

[For Administrators Only] Groups, meetings, and other activities are scheduled in the evenings or on weekends so as not to conflict with other recovery-oriented activities such as employment or school. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_administrator_schedule)

This program offers specific services that fit each participant’s unique culture and life experiences. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_provider_cultural_acceptance)

Staff offer participants opportunities to discuss their spiritual needs and interests when they wish. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_provider_spiritual_needs)

Staff offer participants opportunities to discuss their sexual needs and interests when they wish. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_provider_sexual_needs)

Staff help program participants to develop and plan for life goals beyond managing symptoms or staying stable (e.g., employment, education, physical fitness, connecting with family and friends, hobbies). Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_provider_life_goals)
Staff routinely assist program participants with getting jobs. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_provider_job_search)

Staff actively help program participants to get involved in non-mental health/addiction related activities, such as church groups, adult education, sports, or hobbies. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_provider_other_activities)

Staff work hard to help program participants to include people who are important to them in their recovery/treatment planning (such as family, friends, clergy, or an employer). Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_provider_support_network)

Staff actively introduce program participants to persons in recovery who can serve as role models or mentors. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_provider_role_models)

Staff actively connect program participants with self- help, peer support, or consumer advocacy groups and programs. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_provider_network)

Staff actively help people find ways to give back to their community (i.e., volunteering, community services, neighborhood watch/cleanup). Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_provider_volunteering)

People in recovery are encouraged to help staff with the development of new groups, programs, or services. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_provider_new_development)

People in recovery are encouraged to be involved in the evaluation of this agency’s programs, services, and service providers. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_provider_evaluation)

People in recovery are encouraged to attend agency advisory boards and management meetings. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_provider_attend_meetings)

Staff talk with program participants about what it takes to complete or exit the program. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_provider_complete_program)
Progress made towards an individual’s own personal goals is tracked regularly. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_provider_personal_goals)

The primary role of agency staff is to assist a person with fulfilling his/her own goals and aspirations. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_provider_assist)

Persons in recovery are involved with facilitating staff trainings and education at this program. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_provider_help_train)
Staff at this program regularly attend trainings on cultural competency. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_provider_staff_training)

Staff are knowledgeable about special interest groups and activities in the community. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_provider_specialinterest_groups)
Agency staff are diverse in terms of culture, ethnicity, lifestyle, and interests. Rate on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree) (recovery_selfassessment_provider_diversity)

protocol.longName: Perception of Recovery Orientation and Care Quality of Mental Health Services - Provider Version
protocol.preferredDefinition: The Recovery Self-Assessment (RSA) provider version is a 32-item, provider- completed rating scale that focuses on perceptions of recovery principles and overall quality of services, including determination, staff helpfulness, and staff responsiveness. The RSA includes six subscales: life goals, consumer involvement, diversity of treatment options, consumer choice, individually tailored services, and inviting environment. Each item is rated on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree; 5 = Strongly agree). Ratings from the individual items can be added together to yield a total score, with the higher scores indicating greater quality care.

form.longName: PhenX PX661701 - Multidimensional Assessment Of Antipsychotic Medication
form.preferredDefinition: The Glasgow Antipsychotic Side-effect Scale (GASS) is a 22-item, self-administered checklist that captures a patientÕs viewpoint about suffering from excessive side effects from the antipsychotic medication. Questions 1-20 relate to the previous week and questions 21-22 to the last three months. For questions 1-20, "never" = 0 points, "once" = 1 points, "a few times" = 2 points, and "everyday" = 3 points. For questions 21- 22, "yes" = 3 points and "no" = 0 points. All items are added together to give a total score and higher scores reflect more frequent experience of side effects.

question.questionText: What is your name? (sideeffect_scale_name)
What is your age? (sideeffect_scale_age)
What is your sex? (sideeffect_scale_sex)
Please list current medication and total daily doses below: (sideeffect_scale_medications)
I felt sleepy during the day (sideeffect_scale_sleepiness)
I felt drugged or like a zombie (sideeffect_scale_drugged)
I felt dizzy when I stood up and or or have fainted (sideeffect_scale_dizziness)
I have felt my heart beating irregularly or unusually fast (sideeffect_scale_heart_irregularities)
My muscles have been tense or jerky (sideeffect_scale_muscle_tense)
My hands or arms have been shaky (sideeffect_scale_shaky_hands)
My legs have felt restless and or or I couldn't sit still (sideeffect_scale_restless_legs)
I have been drooling (sideeffect_scale_drooling)
My movements or walking have been slower than usual (sideeffect_scale_slow_movement)
I have had, or people have noticed uncontrollable movements of my face or body (sideeffect_scale_uncontrollable_movement)
My vision has been blurry (sideeffect_scale_blurry_vision)
My mouth has been dry (sideeffect_scale_dry_mouth)
I have had difficulty passing urine (sideeffect_scale_difficulty_urinating)
I have felt like I am going to be sick or have vomited (sideeffect_scale_nausea)
I have wet the bed (sideeffect_scale_bed_wetting)
I have been very thirsty and or or passing urine frequently (sideeffect_scale_thirsty)
The areas around my nipples have been sore and swollen (sideeffect_scale_sensitive_nipples)
I have noticed fluid coming from my nipples (sideeffect_scale_nipple_fluid)
I have had problems enjoying sex (sideeffect_scale_sexual_problems)
Men only: I have had problems getting an erection (sideeffect_scale_erection_problems)
Women only: I have noticed a change in my periods (sideeffect_scale_menstrual_cycle)
Men and women: I have been gaining weight (sideeffect_scale_weight_gain)

protocol.longName: Multi-dimensional Assessment of Antipsychotic Medication Side Effects
protocol.preferredDefinition: The Glasgow Antipsychotic Side-effect Scale (GASS) is a 22-item, self-administered checklist that captures a patientÕs viewpoint about suffering from excessive side effects from the antipsychotic medication. Questions 1-20 relate to the previous week and questions 21-22 to the last three months. For questions 1-20, "never" = 0 points, "once" = 1 points, "a few times" = 2 points, and "everyday" = 3 points. For questions 21- 22, "yes" = 3 points and "no" = 0 points. All items are added together to give a total score and higher scores reflect more frequent experience of side effects.

form.longName: PhenX PX710302 - Susceptibility To Tobacco Products
form.preferredDefinition: The Global Appraisal of Individual Needs (GAIN) Self-Help Involvement Scale (SHIS) is a self-report instrument comprised of 1 item about days attending self-help meetings in the past 90 days, 16 items with yes/no questions about behaviors associated with engaging in self-help in the past 90 days, and 1 item with a check-all-that-apply list of types of self-help meeting involvement.

question.questionText: If one of your friends offered you a cigarette, would you smoke it? (susceptibility_tobacco_friend_cigarette)
At any time during the next 12 months, do you think you will smoke a cigarette? (susceptibility_tobacco_cigarette_past_year)
Do you think you will be smoking cigarettes 5 years from now? (susceptibility_tobacco_cigarette_five_years)
Have you ever been curious about smoking a cigarette? (susceptibility_tobacco_cigarette_curiosity)
Do you think that you will try a cigarette soon? (susceptibility_tobacco_cigarette_try_soon)
If one of your best friends were to offer you a cigarette, would you smoke it? (susceptibility_tobacco_cigarette_friend_encoded)

Have you ever been curious about using an electronic nicotine product? (Electronic nicotine products include e-cigarettes, vape pens, hookah pens, personal vaporizers and mods, e-cigars, e-pipes, and e-hookahs.) (susceptibility_tobacco_electronicproduct_curiosity)
Do you think that you will try an electronic nicotine product soon? (susceptibility_tobacco_electronicproduct_try_soon)
If one of your best friends were to offer you an electronic nicotine product, would you try it? (susceptibility_tobacco_electronicproduct_friend)
Have you ever been curious about smoking a traditional cigar? (susceptibility_tobacco_cigar_curiosity)
Do you think that you will try a traditional cigar soon? (susceptibility_tobacco_cigar_try_soon)
If one of your best friends were to offer you a traditional cigar, would you smoke it? (susceptibility_tobacco_cigar_friend)
Have you ever been curious about smoking a cigarillo? (susceptibility_tobacco_cigarillo_curiosity)
Do you think that you will try a cigarillo soon? (susceptibility_tobacco_cigarillo_try_soon)
If one of your best friends were to offer you a cigarillo, would you smoke it? (susceptibility_tobacco_cigarillo_friend)
Have you ever been curious about smoking a filtered cigar? (susceptibility_tobacco_filteredcigar_curiosity)
Do you think that you will try a filtered cigar soon? (susceptibility_tobacco_filteredcigar_try_soon)
If one of your best friends were to offer you a filtered cigar, would you smoke it? (susceptibility_tobacco_filteredcigar_friend)
Have you ever been curious about smoking a pipe filled with tobacco? (susceptibility_tobacco_pipe_curiosity)
Do you think that you will try smoking a pipe filled with tobacco soon? (susceptibility_tobacco_pipe_try_soon)
If one of your best friends were to offer you a pipe filled with tobacco, would you smoke it? (susceptibility_tobacco_pipe_friend)
Have you ever been curious about smoking tobacco in a hookah? (susceptibility_tobacco_hookah_curiosity)
Do you think that you will try smoking tobacco in a hookah soon? (susceptibility_tobacco_hookah_try_soon)
If one of your best friends were to offer you a hookah, would you try it? (susceptibility_tobacco_hookah_friend)
Have you ever been curious about using smokeless tobacco? (susceptibility_tobacco_smokeless_curiosity)
Do you think that you will try smokeless tobacco soon? (susceptibility_tobacco_smokeless_try_soon)
If one of your best friends were to offer you smokeless tobacco, would you try it? (susceptibility_tobacco_smokeless_friend)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Global Appraisal of Individual Needs (GAIN) Self-Help Involvement Scale (SHIS) is a self-report instrument comprised of 1 item about days attending self-help meetings in the past 90 days, 16 items with yes/no questions about behaviors associated with engaging in self-help in the past 90 days, and 1 item with a check-all-that-apply list of types of self-help meeting involvement.

form.longName: PhenX PX750301 - Social Norms About Tobacco - Adult
form.preferredDefinition: This protocol uses a combination of questions from the 2011 International Tobacco Control (ITC) 4-Country Survey and the Population Assessment of Tobacco and Health (PATH) Survey instruments. Collectively, the questions are used to assess social norms within the adult population by determining whether or not a respondent resides with one or more users of tobacco products; if most people’s and those most important to the respondent’s opinions of using tobacco are positive or negative; and the smoking status of five closest friends or acquaintances.
